Setting the wallpaper action doesn't work on xfce desktop, so I had to find the download location to use my desktop tools to set it. It turned out to be on a really awkward path. I think the developer did this on purpose to enforce security over obscurity. This dumb practice took me ages back to the time that I used windows.

description:
I've recently posted in Facebook in a fist full of Free Code Camp groups about possibly using QRcodes as a way to scan comprehensive learning into a program. My suggestions are that; we have a device to scan QRcodes to relay programming code to a computer, in order to execute conversation with the program. The concept being that the QRcodes will have recognized text from voice-overs not similar to a script read style rather, teaching the program to speak. The program can then scan the QRcode of a phrase(while words will always be scanned and stored catelogged for later suggestions) that it picks up. And everytime the program recognizes the same phrase/word, it realizes that the phrase/word has been taught to it already and then starts scanning QRcodes for comprehensive suggestions. This means that we would have to create a type of risk of disappointment for the program in order to help it realize that it's suggestions are wrong, so that the program then fetches more suggestions in order to win awards. So, if you're up to a challenge? This is the one for the ages!

Admittingly this project is not yet in progress and by no means does Omni Hyphen have an idea of some sort of magic, that can have this project appear out of thin air or even that it's an easy suggestion. This project is going to be time consuming with trial and error. The truth of the matter is; could this be true at all?

description: Its takes some time to open, please optmimize it

working great on Ubuntu 20.04, but restricted to a relatively small number of downloads unless you pay. For linux software that's pretty superfluous, this just feels weird. A donation-based model would almost certainly be more effective in keeping users and generating revenue for the developer. I got bored of the app quickly, which kept me from paying. If I had been using it for a while and periodically asked to donate, I probably would have b/c I tend to give money to any software developer whose products I actually use and enjoy.

Also, without support for different desktops on different monitors, or different desktops per activity space, or different desktops for different user-triggered events or custom time periods, the features of this lag pretty far behind whats easily possible in MacOS. IDK how hard it would be to implement them in Linux, but none of those things sound terribly hard to program even just in BASH, which makes it weird not to see them.
summary: works great but pricey for the service
